title: Lesson 4: Communication and Teaching Skills
description: Leaders communicate constantly - how to teach the Bible clearly, speak with grace and truth, and listen as well as you talk.

content.text: Lessons 1 through 3 have built the external framework of your leadership: vision, people development, and teams. These are the what and the who. But all of it travels through a single medium: communication. A leader's influence is only as wide as their ability to communicate clearly. You can have the best vision in the world, but if you cannot say it in a way that moves people, it stays locked in your head. You can be developing leaders, but if you cannot teach them what you know, they cannot multiply it. You can have a healthy team, but if you do not communicate expectations and feedback, it will fracture. This lesson is about the skill that makes everything else possible: how you talk.
Teaching That Transforms

Most people who teach the Bible do one of two things. Either they focus so hard on getting the words right that the people do not understand. Or they simplify so much that the teaching has no power. Nehemiah 8:8 gives the gold standard. Ezra 'read from the Book of the Law of God, making it clear and giving the meaning of it, so that the people understood what was being read.' Three moves: read clearly, give the meaning, ensure understanding. This is the model for all teaching. First, explain what the text says. Do not assume people know the Bible. Do not assume they understand the language. Make it clear. Second, explain what it means. What did this mean to the original audience? What is the truth being revealed? What is the principle underneath it? Third, explain what to do with it. How does this change how I think? How does this change how I live? What is the one thing I should do differently this week? The goal of teaching is not to display knowledge. The goal is to produce understanding that leads to change.
They read from the Book of the Law of God, making it clear and giving the meaning of it, so that the people understood what was being read.
Rate yourself 1 to 10 as a teacher or communicator of Scripture. What is one thing that would move you up a single point?
When you prepare to teach, do you cover all three moves (what it says, what it means, what to do with it)? Which one do you tend to rush or skip?
Everyday Communication

Most leaders think communication is what happens from the front of a room. But Colossians 4:6 is clear that this is much bigger: 'Let your speech always be gracious, seasoned with salt, so that you may know how to answer each person.' This covers everything. A conversation over coffee. A difficult email. A hard conversation with someone who has disappointed you. An encouragement to someone who is discouraged. Every conversation is a leadership moment. People are watching how you talk to the junior person on the team just as much as how you talk to the major donor. People are noticing if you gossip. They are noticing if you listen or just wait for your turn to talk. They are noticing if you keep confidences. The standard is gracious speech, seasoned with salt. Gracious means kind, generous, full of grace. Seasoned with salt means it has substance. It has truth in it. It is not cheap encouragement. It is not gossip dressed up as concern. It is truth told with kindness. This is the gold standard for everything you say.
Let your conversation be always full of grace, seasoned with salt, so that you may know how to answer each person.
Think about your conversations this week. How many were gracious? How many were seasoned with salt? Where do you tend to miss the mark?
Describe your preparation process for teaching Scripture. What do you do well? What is one area where you could improve?
The Underrated Skill: Listening

Leaders love to talk. It is in the job description. But the most overlooked leadership skill is listening. The leader who only broadcasts never learns what their people actually need. A leader who asks a question and then waits, really waits, to hear the answer will learn more in that conversation than they could tell in an hour of talking. Proverbs 18:13 is harsh but true: 'If one gives an answer before he hears, it is his folly and shame.' Before you offer your wisdom, you need to understand the situation. Before you give direction, you need to know what the person is actually struggling with. Before you solve a problem, you need to ask questions. Listen to what they are not saying, too. Notice where they hesitate. Notice what makes them emotional. Notice what they keep coming back to. Sometimes a question is more powerful than an answer. A leader who has trained themselves to listen creates safety. People feel heard. They open up. They trust you with things they would never tell a leader who is just waiting for a chance to speak. Listening is not passive. It is deeply active. It requires focus, humility, and patience.
If one gives an answer before he hears, it is his folly and shame.
Think about a conversation where you did most of the talking. What would have happened if you had asked more questions and listened more?
Who in your life tells you things you do not want to hear? Do you actually listen to them, or do you defend yourself?
Closing Reflections
What is the one key insight from this lesson about communication and teaching?
What is one step you will take this week to improve your communication or listening?
How will you pray about your words and the impact of your communication?
